Matrix size

Matrices can be of any size as long as the entries form a rectangular array. We say that an \(m \times n\) matrix is a matrix with \(m\) rows and \(n\) columns. For example \[ \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \\ 5& 6 \end{bmatrix} \] is a \(3 \times 2\) matrix because it has three rows and two columns. A matrix which has a size of \(1 \times n\) is called a row vector because it is a matrix consisting of one row. Similarly, a matrix of size \(n \times 1\) is called a column vector because it is a matrix consisting of one column. The entries of a matrix are called the elements of the matrix, most often these will be numbers.


A matrix that has the same number of rows as columns is called a square matrix, these are one of the most important types of matrices.
